{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} {{infobox film | name = Raman Raghav 2.0 | image = Raman Raghav 2.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Anurag Kashyap]] | producer = Anurag Kashyap
[[Vikas Bahl]]
[[Vikramaditya Motwane]]
[[Madhu Mantena]] | writer = Anurag Kashyap
Vasan Bala | starring = [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui]]
[[Sobhita Dhulipala]]
[[Vicky Kaushal]] | music = [[Ram Sampath]] | editing = [[Aarti Bajaj]] | cinematography = Jay Oza | studio = [[Phantom Films]] | distributor = [[Reliance Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|2016|5|16|[[2016 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]|2016|06|24|India|df=yes}} | runtime = 127 minutes{{cite news|url=http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/raman-raghav-20-review/5104024.article|title='Raman Raghav 2.0': Review|last=Ide|first=Wendy|work=[[Screen International]]|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=22 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521035059/http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/raman-raghav-20-review/5104024.article|archivedate=21 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} | country = India | language = Hindi | budget = ₹35 million{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/raman-raghav-2-0-to-lisa-haydon-ten-epic-quotes-by-anurag-kashyap-on-films-and-feminism-2808782.html|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' to Lisa Haydon: Ten epic quotes by Anurag Kashyap on films and feminism|last=Ramakrishnan|first=Swetha|work=[[Firstpost]]|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=15 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160606050314/http://www.firstpost.com/politics/raman-raghav-2-0-to-lisa-haydon-ten-epic-quotes-by-anurag-kashyap-on-films-and-feminism-2808782.html|archivedate=6 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} | gross = ₹70 million{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/raman-raghav-2-0/box-office/|title=Raman Raghav 2.0: Box Office|publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]]|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724113936/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/raman-raghav-2-0/box-office/|archivedate=24 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} }} '''''Raman Raghav 2.0''''' (released internationally as '''''Psycho Raman''''') is a 2016 Indian [[neo-noir]], [[psychological thriller|psychological-thriller]] film directed by [[Anurag Kashyap]]. Produced by Kashyap, [[Vikramaditya Motwane]], [[Vikas Bahl|Vikas Bahl,]] and [[Madhu Mantena]], the film stars [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui]], [[Vicky Kaushal]], and debutante [[Sobhita Dhulipala]]. It depicts in eight chapters the [[cat and mouse]] chase of serial killer Ramanna (Siddiqui) by corrupt cop Raghavan (Kaushal). Real-life killer [[Raman Raghav]], who operated in Mumbai during the 1960s, inspired the film. Kashyap initially wanted to make a period film about Raman Raghav, but after the commercial failure of ''[[Bombay Velvet]]'' (2015), his previous film also set in the 1960s, he realised that he would be unable to find financing. Abandoning the period-piece concept, he co-wrote the film with Vasan Bala, setting it in the contemporary time. The film's music was composed by [[Ram Sampath]], and [[Varun Grover]] wrote the lyrics. Jay Oza served as the film's cinematographer and [[Aarti Bajaj]] as its editor. ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' premiered in the [[Directors' Fortnight]] section at the [[2016 Cannes Film Festival]]. It also screened at the 2016 [[Sydney Film Festival]], the [[Singapore International Film Festival]], the [[Fantasia International Film Festival]], [[Bucheon International Fantastic Film Festival]], and the [[Indian Film Festival of Melbourne]]. The film was released in India on 24 June 2016, received a mostly positive critical response, and proved to be a moderate commercial success, grossing over ₹70 million (US$1.1 million). == Plot == In 2013 Assistant Commissioner of Police Raghavan Amrendra Singh Umbi, a drug addict, makes a visit to a Mumbai drug dealer. However, his plan to purchase drugs is foiled – the dealer and another man have been murdered. Investigating the murders the next day, he receives a hammer followed by an anonymous phone call. In 2015 a man named Ramanna surrenders to the police and confesses of killing nine people. He is detained and beaten by the police, but manages to escape with the help of a group of nearby boys. Seeking food at the home of his sister Lakshmi, Ramanna argues with his brother-in-law. After leaving the house he quickly returns and kills the couple and their son. Raghavan is among the police who later investigate the house, where he finds a picture of Ramanna with Lakshmi, confirming Ramanna's involvement in the crime. Raghavan is in a relationship with Smrutika "Simi" Naidu, but he is an abusive partner: he beats her and has coerced her to have three abortions. Ramanna surveils Raghavan and Simi, suggesting some kind of link exists between the cop and the killer. This surveillance escalates into more murders when Ramanna stalks and kills Simi's maid and her husband. After these killings, Ramanna is caught by the police with assistance from an onlooker. However, Ramanna escapes from custody again and kills the man who aided his capture. Raghavan proves to be a killer himself when, on a trip to visit his father, he murders an African drug dealer. On a later evening Raghavan picks up another woman named Ankita at a nightclub and brings her to Simi's house. Incapacitated by his drug use, Raghavan is unable to perform sexually, prompting mockery from Ankita. In response he assaults her. Enraged, he searches for the stash of drugs he keeps at the house, but is unable to find it. In this state he confronts Simi and they argue. When Simi demands he leave with Ankita, he strikes Simi; her fall into a glass table kills her instantly. Ankita locks herself in the bathroom and tries to call for help, but desists when Raghavan threatens and coerces her. He then clears away incriminating evidence and arranges the scene to implicate Ramanna for the murder. He retrieves a tire iron similar to Ramanna's favored murder weapon and smashes Simi's head with it. During these preparations Ankita escapes. The next day Ramanna surrenders to Raghavan and claims a deep connection with him: each man is the missing half of the other. Ramanna also reveals his role in the two 2013 murders that opened the film and initiated this connection. He confesses to one of the killings, but witnessed Raghavan kill the other man, and thus began his surveillance of the policeman. Ramanna offers to accept the charge for Simi's murder, but only if Raghavan will kill the eyewitness, Ankita. In the final scene Raghavan's descent into evil matches Ramanna's when he murders Ankita in her home. == Cast == * [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui]] as Ramanna * [[Vicky Kaushal]] as ACP Raghavan Singh * [[Sobhita Dhulipala]] as Smrutika "Simi" Naidu * [[Vipin Sharma]] as Raghav's father * [[Amruta Subhash]] as Lakshmi * [[Ashok Lokhande]] as Lakshmi's husband * [[Harssh A. Singh]] as sub-inspector * Anuschka Sawhney as Ankita * Hitesh Dave as Constable Kamble * Rajesh Jais as Farid Haq * Kalidas Parthitan as Michael * Rhea Pagar as Violet * Arun Singh as Swamiji == Production == === Development === ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' was inspired by the notorious serial killer [[Raman Raghav]], who had killed several homeless people in Mumbai during the late 1960s.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/double-indemnity-whats-common-between-anurag-kashyap-and-sriram-raghavan-2834858/|title=Double Indemnity: What’s common between Anurag Kashyap and Sriram Raghavan?|last=Sahani|first=Alaka|date=6 June 2016|work=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=3 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105122936/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/double-indemnity-whats-common-between-anurag-kashyap-and-sriram-raghavan-2834858/|archivedate=5 November 2016|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} Bludgeoning his victims, he produced widespread panic until he was captured by the Mumbai police and confessed to 41 murders.{{cite web|url=http://www.scoopwhoop.com/The-Real-Raman-Raghav-Serial-Killer-Anurag-Kashyap/|title=All You Need To Know About Raman Raghav, The Serial Killer Who Inspired Anurag Kashyap's Next|last=Kasotia|first=Yash|work=[[ScoopWhoop]]|date=11 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516153128/http://www.scoopwhoop.com/The-Real-Raman-Raghav-Serial-Killer-Anurag-Kashyap|archivedate=16 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} Raghav was sentenced to death by the [[Bombay High Court]], but his diagnosis of [[paranoid schizophrenia]] allowed his defence to [[Insanity defense|claim mental incapability]] and gain a change of sentence to life imprisonment.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/inside-the-mind-of-raman-raghav-mumbai-s-serial-killer-of-the-60s/story-LaA01MtT0wrAM0ZprCoLYJ.html|title=Inside the mind of Raman Raghav, Mumbai's serial killer of the 60s|last=Saxena|first=Poonam|date=14 June 2016|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|accessdate=3 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927110217/http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/inside-the-mind-of-raman-raghav-mumbai-s-serial-killer-of-the-60s/story-LaA01MtT0wrAM0ZprCoLYJ.html|archivedate=27 September 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} He was sent to [[Yerawada Central Jail]], where he died of kidney failure in 1988 after 19 years of incarceration. Director Anurag Kashyap first became interested in the story of Raman Raghav in 1991, when [[Sriram Raghavan]] was making a 68-minute film about the killer titled ''Raman Raghav, A City, A Killer''. Kashyap was drawn to the idea of a criminal who was not motivated by familiar human vices. According to him, the killer had "no moral compass" or planning to kill someone. He initially wanted to make a trilogy of period films based in Mumbai, the first of which was ''[[Bombay Velvet]]'' (2015), then a film on the [[K. M. Nanavati v. State of Maharashtra|Nanavati murder case]] after ''Raman Raghav 2.0''. But after the commercial failure of ''Bombay Velvet'', Kashyap realised that he would not get producers for another period film. He then set the film in contemporary time. The film on the Nanavati case did not materialise. Vasan Bala, the film's co-writer, had written a biopic about Raman Raghav. Kashyap re-wrote that script, taking inspirations from the actual murders.{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/GIhSzHnmawwpBr4erYfKvN/Anurag-Kashyap-David-Dhawan-of-lowbudget.html|title=Anurag Kashyap: David Dhawan of low-budget films|last=Jhunjhunwala|first=Udita|work=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]|date=3 June 2016|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107011843/http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/GIhSzHnmawwpBr4erYfKvN/Anurag-Kashyap-David-Dhawan-of-lowbudget.html|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} He created a police officer who would be the "mirror image" of the killer, as he felt it was difficult to create an honest cop in a contemporary time. === Casting === [[File:Tire iron.jpg|thumb|right|A [[tire iron]], similar to one used in the film.]] Kashyap said that [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui]] was his first casting choice for the film because of his "unimposing body". Kashyap modeled the character on [[Raghubir Yadav]], who had portrayed Raman Raghav in Sriram Raghavan's 1991 film. For the preparation of the role, Siddiqui isolated himself for days, left his house. He mentioned that he started to "fear himself".{{cite news|url=http://www.abplive.in/movies/nawazuddin-left-home-started-fearing-himself-while-preparing-for-raman-raghav-2-0-339285|title=Nawazuddin left home, started fearing himself while preparing for 'Raman Raghav 2.0'|date=10 May 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160518112754/http://www.abplive.in/movies/nawazuddin-left-home-started-fearing-himself-while-preparing-for-raman-raghav-2-0-339285|archivedate=18 May 2016|deadurl=no|publisher=[[ABP News]]|df=dmy-all}} [[Vicky Kaushal]] was called by Kashyap and was give two scenes to prepare in five days for the audition. Kaushal locked himself in the room and isolated himself from phone, internet and newspaper and kept repeating his lines from the scenes.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/i-badly-want-to-do-an-action-film/20160516.htm|title='I badly want to do an action film'|last=N|first=Patcy|date=16 May 2016|publisher=[[Rediff.com]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520120929/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/i-badly-want-to-do-an-action-film/20160516.htm|archivedate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=20 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} He then gave the audition and was selected for the role of Raghav. [[Miss Earth India]] 2013, [[Sobhita Dhulipala]] made her acting debut with this film.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/sobhita-dhulipala-on-her-debut-film-raman-raghav-20/article8594389.ece|title=Sobhita's dream debut in 'Raman Raghav 2.0'|last=Ganguly|first=Nivedita|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=13 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016}} She had got a call for audition from the casting director [[Mukesh Chhabra]], where she was eventually selected.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/i-want-to-try-everything-says-raman-raghav-2-0-actor-sobhita-dhulipala-2877321/|title=I want to try everything, says Raman Raghav 2.0 actor Sobhita Dhulipala|last=Gaikwad|first=Pramod|date=26 June 2016|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=3 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107010259/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/i-want-to-try-everything-says-raman-raghav-2-0-actor-sobhita-dhulipala-2877321/|archivedate=7 November 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} === Filming === The principal photography began in September 2015 and was completed on 22 November 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.indiatimes.com/entertainment/celebs/anurag-kashyap-has-put-in-herculean-efforts-to-make-raman-raghav-2-0-in-20-days-255203.html|title=Anurag Kashyap Has Put in Herculean Efforts To Make Raman Raghav 2.0 in 20 Days!|last=Sharma|first=Isha|publisher=[[Times Internet]]|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160518101332/http://www.indiatimes.com/entertainment/celebs/anurag-kashyap-has-put-in-herculean-efforts-to-make-raman-raghav-2-0-in-20-days-255203.html|archivedate=18 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Vicky-straightens-up-psycho-Nawaz-in-Anurag-Kashyaps-psycho-thriller/articleshow/49147546.cms|title=Vicky straightens up psycho Nawaz in Anurag Kashyap's psycho-thriller|last=Iyer|first=Sanyukta|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=29 September 2015|accessdate=5 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917033900/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Vicky-straightens-up-psycho-Nawaz-in-Anurag-Kashyaps-psycho-thriller/articleshow/49147546.cms|archivedate=17 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151122/entertainment-bollywood/article/anurag-kashyap-wraps-raman-raghav-20|title=Anurag Kashyap wraps up 'Raman Raghav 2.0'|work=[[Deccan Chronicle]]|date=22 November 2015|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123183956/http://deccanchronicle.com/151122/entertainment-bollywood/article/anurag-kashyap-wraps-raman-raghav-20|archivedate=23 November 2015|df=dmy-all}} Kashyap wrote smaller scenes: "Normal Hindi films have 70 scenes, my films have 220 scenes".{{cite web|url=http://www.scoopwhoop.com/How-Anurag-Kashyap-Made-Raman-Raghav-20-With-A-Shoestring-Budget-Will-Leave-You-Awestruck/|title=How Anurag Kashyap Made Raman Raghav 2.0 with a Shoestring Budget Will Leave You Awestruck|last=Sharma|first=Sampada|work=ScoopWhoop|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520092736/http://www.scoopwhoop.com/How-Anurag-Kashyap-Made-Raman-Raghav-20-With-A-Shoestring-Budget-Will-Leave-You-Awestruck|archivedate=20 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} He mentioned that it helped in making the film look vast as the locations kept changing. The title was decided before the script was ready. The crew employed [[guerrilla filmmaking]] technique to shoot in real locations of Mumbai.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/05/12/nawazuddin-siddiqui-raman_n_9921868.html|title=INTERVIEW: Nawazuddin Siddiqui On The Method To His Madness In Anurag Kashyap's 'Raman Raghav 2.0'|last=Chatterjee|first=Suprateek|work=[[HuffPost]]|date=12 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521131826/http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/05/12/nawazuddin-siddiqui-raman_n_9921868.html|archivedate=21 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} Siddiqui had to deliver a ten-minute monologue in the film. To maintain [[Continuity (fiction)|continuity]], he had to be still at the same place while the camera setup was changed from different angles.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/when-nawazuddin-siddiqui-spoke-for-300-minutes-in-raman-raghav-2-0-2822374/|title=When Nawazuddin Siddiqui spoke for 300 minutes in Raman Raghav 2.0|work=The Indian Express|date=27 May 2016|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020757/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/when-nawazuddin-siddiqui-spoke-for-300-minutes-in-raman-raghav-2-0-2822374/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} As a result, he ended up speaking for 300 minutes in the same position. After the shoot, the actor experienced a blackout and could not talk for sometime. Kaushal's character is shown snorting [[cocaine]] throughout the film. To make a quasi-cocaine powder, the crew used Glucon-D and Corn Starch.{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-you-won-t-believe-what-vicky-kaushal-snorted-while-shooting-for-raman-raghav-20-2218426|title=You won't believe what Vicky Kaushal snorted while shooting for Raman Raghav 2.0|work=[[Daily News and Analysis]]|date=31 May 2016|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107234801/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-you-won-t-believe-what-vicky-kaushal-snorted-while-shooting-for-raman-raghav-20-2218426|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} Kaushal practiced inhaling the powder for his scenes in the film. While shooting in some unhygienic surroundings, Siddiqui fell ill and was hospitalised for five days. His wife later said that Siddiqui was repeating his dialogues from the film, while being semi-conscious on bed. Although the diagnosis showed [[Dengue fever|dengue]] initially, he recovered quickly. He resumed shooting for the film when he was discharged. Siddiqui called the shoot a "mentally draining" experience.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/raman-raghav-2-0-was-mentally-draining-nawazuddin-siddiqui-2791545/|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 was mentally draining: Nawazuddin Siddiqui|work=The Indian Express|date=9 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510235447/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/raman-raghav-2-0-was-mentally-draining-nawazuddin-siddiqui-2791545/|archivedate=10 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} For a scene, the crew had to shoot it in the restricted area of the [[Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport|Mumbai airport]] which is guarded by snipers with strict instructions to shoot any infiltrator. Siddiqui was told not to move from his position and the scene was shot.{{cite web|url=https://www.indiatvnews.com/entertainment/bollywood-nawazuddin-siddiqui-raman-raghav-2-0-life-at-risk-331008|title=Did Nawazuddin Siddiqui put his life at risk for Raman Raghav 2.0?|publisher=[[India TV]]|date=25 May 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830034353/http://www.indiatvnews.com/entertainment/bollywood-nawazuddin-siddiqui-raman-raghav-2-0-life-at-risk-331008|archivedate=30 August 2016|df=dmy-all}} The [[visual effects]] and title sequence for the film were executed by Mumbai-based VFX and animation studio, Plexus.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/reviews/psycho-raman-review-1201775545/|title=Cannes Film Review: ‘Psycho Raman’|last=Lodge|first=Guy|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=22 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521022210/http://variety.com/2016/film/reviews/psycho-raman-review-1201775545/|archivedate=21 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} [[Aarti Bajaj]] and Jay Oza served as the editor and director of photography respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/raman-raghav-2-0/cast/|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 Cast & Crew|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028053326/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/raman-raghav-2-0/cast/|archivedate=28 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' was distributed by [[Reliance Entertainment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.relianceentertainment.net/pdf/Press%20Release_12Dec16.pdf|title=Reliance Entertainment, Phantom Films and Kev Adams Launch Unique Indo-French Partnership for Two Movies|publisher=Reliance Entertainment|date=12 December 2016|accessdate=23 May 2018|format=pdf}} == Soundtrack == {{Infobox album | name = Raman Raghav 2.0 | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Ram Sampath]] | cover = | alt = | released = 3 June 2016 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack|Feature film Soundtrack]] | length = 19:00 | language = [[Hindi]] | label = [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]] | producer = | prev_title = [[Bangistan]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = [[Raees (film)|Raees]] | next_year = 2017 }} The film's soundtrack and background score was composed by [[Ram Sampath]], while the lyrics were penned by [[Varun Grover]]. The album rights were acquired by [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]], and it was released on 3 June 2016.{{cite web|url=https://gaana.com/album/raman-raghav-20|title=Raman Raghav 2.0|publisher=[[Gaana.com]]|accessdate=28 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228171855/https://gaana.com/album/raman-raghav-20|archivedate=28 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/exclusive-raman-raghav-2-0-launches-music-in-style-2831275/|title=Exclusive: Raman Raghav 2.0 launches music in style|work=The Indian Express|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=28 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228172540/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/exclusive-raman-raghav-2-0-launches-music-in-style-2831275/|archivedate=28 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} The first song launched was "Qatl-e-aam", which Sampath described as a "unique blend of Ghazal & Hard Trance". [[Sona Mohapatra]], Nayantara Bhatkal, [[Siddharth Basrur]] and Ram Sampath provided vocals for the album's songs.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/raman-raghav-2-0-original-motion-picture-soundtrack-ep/1158812174|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) – EP|publisher=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411072311/https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/raman-raghav-2-0-original-motion-picture-soundtrack-ep/1158812174|archivedate=11 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} The film's soundtrack received a mixed response from critics. Swetha Ramakrishnan of ''[[Firstpost]]'' called the soundtrack, "sensual, sinister" and "eclectic". She called the unplugged version of Mohapatra's "Qatl-E-Aam" as "cleaner, more powerful rendition".{{cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/raman-raghav-2-0-music-review-kudos-ram-sampath-for-this-sensual-sinister-soundtrack-2847304.html|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' music review: Kudos Ram Sampath, for this sensual, sinister soundtrack|last=Ramakrishnan|first=Swetha|work=Firstpost|date=22 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411072312/https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/raman-raghav-2-0-music-review-kudos-ram-sampath-for-this-sensual-sinister-soundtrack-2847304.html|archivedate=11 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} Tatsam Mukherjee of ''[[India Today]]'' said the music is "every indie musician's angsty reply to everything wrong with Bollywood 'phillum' music." He described Bhatkal's vocal in "Behooda" as something that "lends the song a very gangster-like feel with the continuous violin, keyboard riffs accompanying the chorus."{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/raman-raghav-2.0-special/story/raman-raghav-2-0-music-review-nawazuddin-siddiqui-anurag-kashyap-ram-sampath-songs-12627-2016-06-06|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 music review: Ram Sampath is back to Bollywood|last=Mukherjee|first=Tatsam|work=[[India Today]]|date=6 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411072311/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/raman-raghav-2.0-special/story/raman-raghav-2-0-music-review-nawazuddin-siddiqui-anurag-kashyap-ram-sampath-songs-12627-2016-06-06|archivedate=11 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} Writing for [[Rediff.com]], Aelina Kapoor described the soundtrack as "unconventional score that matches the filmmaker's unorthodox reputation". She said the song "Paani Ka Raasta" has a poetic touch with dark undertones.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-raman-raghav-20s-music-is-experimental/20160611.htm|title=Review: Raman Raghav 2.0's music is experimental|last=Kapoor|first=Aelina|publisher=Rediff.com|date=11 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014234002/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-raman-raghav-20s-music-is-experimental/20160611.htm|archivedate=14 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} Manish Gaekwad thought that "Raghav's Theme" has a "hybrid sound in which techno music meets the sarangi to create a hypnotic instrumental track that explores the psyche of its protagonist."{{cite web|url=https://scroll.in/reel/809417/soundtrack-review-raman-raghav-2-0-can-get-loud-and-relentless|title=Soundtrack review: ‘Raman Raghav 2.0’ can get loud and relentless|last=Gaekwad|first=Manish|publisher=Scroll.in|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=10 April Murders|publisher=[[AlloCiné]]|accessdate=17 November 2018}} == Reception == === Critical reception === ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' received mostly positive response from critics upon its theatrical release.{{cite web|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.in/raman-raghav-2-0-review-round-here-what-critics-have-say-about-nawazuddin-starrer-684081|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' movie review round-up: Here is what critics have to say about Nawazuddin-starrer|last=Mehta|first=Ankita|work=International Business Times|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621051143/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/raman-raghav-2-0-review-round-here-what-critics-have-say-about-nawazuddin-starrer-684081|archivedate=21 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} Saibal Chattejee of [[NDTV]] praised the "gripping, visceral genre film", and described the villain as "a cross between ''[[No Country for Old Men (film)|No Country for Old Men']]''s [[Anton Chigurh]] and ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Se7en']]''s John Doe".{{cite web|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/raman-raghav-2-0-movie-review-1280|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 Movie Review|last=Chatterjee|first=Saibal|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211030702/http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/raman-raghav-2-0-movie-review-1280|archivedate=11 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} Writing for ''[[The Hindu]]'', Namrata Joshi called ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' a "taut thriller" that "takes you on an entertainment high."{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/Raman-Raghav-2.0-A-clear-cut-uncomplicated-thriller/article14399309.ece|title='Raman Raghav 2.0': A clear-cut, uncomplicated, thriller|last=Joshi|first=Namrata|date=24 June 2016|work=The Hindu|accessdate=10 April 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161205172336/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/Raman-Raghav-2.0-A-clear-cut-uncomplicated-thriller/article14399309.ece|archivedate=5 December 2016|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} [[Anna M. M. Vetticad]] praised Siddiqui for his "eerie, scary, [and] disgusting" portrayal of the serial killer, and was particularly impressed by his ability to elicit laughs "for the matter-of-fact manner in which he goes about his bloody business".{{cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/raman-raghav-2-0-review-anurag-kashyap-vicky-nawaz-take-a-bow-2853234.html|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' review: Anurag Kashyap, Vicky, Nawaz – take a bow|last=Vetticad|first=Anna MM|work=Firstpost|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112145250/http://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/raman-raghav-2-0-review-anurag-kashyap-vicky-nawaz-take-a-bow-2853234.html|archivedate=12 January 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mohar Basu of ''[[The Times of India]]'' wrote, "It is crude, callous and keeps you in suspense all through". He felt that it was a difficult film to watch as it made the viewer "queasy".{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/movie-reviews/raman-raghav-2-0/movie-review/52887915.cms|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 Movie Review|work=The Times of India|date=2 August 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108193042/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/movie-reviews/Raman-Raghav-2-0/movie-review/52887915.cms|archivedate=8 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} Aseem Chhabra shared the view of the film being a "difficult watch". Although he was critical of the film's [[misogyny]] that made it a "difficult film to admire", he praised Siddiqui's performance at his "creepiest best".{{cite news|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-raman-raghav-20-a-difficult-watch/20160624.htm|title=Review: Raman Raghav 2.0: A difficult watch|last=Chhabra|first=Aseem|publisher=Rediff.com|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925121815/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-raman-raghav-20-a-difficult-watch/20160624.htm|archivedate=25 September 2017|df=dmy-all}} Sweta Kaushal of ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' described the film as "spine-chilling" and "pure sadism".{{cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/movie-reviews/raman-raghav-2-0-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-and-vicky-take-you-on-a-sadistic-trippy-ride/story-Cii8JUNm6KQJdsXZnt0yfN.html|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 review: A deadly killer is roaming around us|last=Kaushal|first=Sweta|work=Hindustan Times|date=26 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513233020/http://www.hindustantimes.com/movie-reviews/raman-raghav-2-0-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-and-vicky-take-you-on-a-sadistic-trippy-ride/story-Cii8JUNm6KQJdsXZnt0yfN.html|archivedate=13 May 2017|df=dmy-all}} Contrary to the positive critical reviews, [[Rajeev Masand]] felt the film "doesn't bring anything blazingly new or original to the serial killer genre."{{cite web|url=http://www.rajeevmasand.com/reviews/our-films/going-for-the-kill/|title=Going for the kill|last=Masand|first=Rajeev|publisher=RajeevMasand.com|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171007100911/http://www.rajeevmasand.com/reviews/our-films/going-for-the-kill/|archivedate=7 October 2017|df=dmy-all}} Shubhra Gupta of ''[[The Indian Express]]'' wrote that the film was "atmospheric yet hollow" and the viewers are "turned into cringing voyeurs, into reluctant participants, without redemption".{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/movie-review/raman-raghav-2-0-movie-review-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-siddique-2872741/|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 movie review: With few mesmeric bits, Anurag Kashyap’s film is atmospheric yet hollow|last=Gupta|first=Shubhra|work=The Indian Express|date=25 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810070518/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/movie-review/raman-raghav-2-0-movie-review-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-siddique-2872741/|archivedate=10 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Ananya Bhattacharya of ''[[India Today]]'' praised the film but felt that Dhulipala's character was the "weak link" as she "doesn't have much to do".{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/raman-raghav-2-movie-review-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-siddiqui-16026-2016-06-24|title=Raman Raghav 2.0 Movie Review|last=Bhattacharya|first=Ananya|work=India Today|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411072311/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/raman-raghav-2-movie-review-anurag-kashyap-nawazuddin-siddiqui-16026-2016-06-24|archivedate=11 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} Among the overseas reviewers, Deborah Young of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' noted Kaushal's performance and lack of character-depth of female characters, "Variety and depth of character are badly lacking on the female front, weakening the whole film."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/psycho-raman-raman-raghav-20-894381|title='Psycho Raman' ('Raman Raghav 2.0'): Cannes Review|last=Young|first=Deborah|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=22 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520145936/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/psycho-raman-raman-raghav-20-894381|archivedate=20 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} [[Maitland McDonagh]] commented that the film performs a "surprisingly deep dive into lust, murder and violent obsession" and "delivers a couple of truly suspenseful sequences."{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/reviews/film-review-raman-raghav-20|title=Film Review: Raman Raghav 2.0|last=McDonagh|first=Maitland|work=[[Film Journal International]]|date=23 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201092837/http://www.filmjournal.com/reviews/film-review-raman-raghav-20|archivedate=1 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} Guy Lodge from ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' mentioned it as a "luridly absorbing serial killer thriller" and felt Siddiqui's performance has an "unblinking intensity". Wendy Ide from ''[[Screen International]]'' reviewed the film and called it a "propulsive and bloodthirsty thriller" and a "adrenalised energy which rarely flags." But he felt that the film lacks the sense of a "Manhunter-style battle of wits." Patrick Cooper of [[Bloody Disgusting]] wrote about the film, "If you only think of Bollywood when you think of Indian film, Psycho Raman will knock some sense into you, as it stands up with the grittiest American serial killer thrillers." Suprateek Chatterjee of ''[[HuffPost]]'' mentioned the film as an "exercise in empty shock value".{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/06/24/raman-raghav-2-review_n_10648434.html|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' Review: An Exercise In Empty Shock Value|last=Chatterjee|first=Suprateek|work=HuffPost|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501160434/http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/06/24/raman-raghav-2-review_n_10648434.html|archivedate=1 May 2017|df=dmy-all}} === Box office === ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' was made on a production budget of {{INRConvert|35|m}}. Released on the same day as six other films, including ''[[Junooniyat]]'' and the Hollywood film ''[[Independence Day: Resurgence]]'', only ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' earned favourable reviews from the critics. It collected a total of {{INRConvert|12.0|m}} on its opening day and {{INRConvert|13.6|m}} on its second day, making a total of {{INRConvert|24.6|m}}. At the end of the opening weekend, the film grossed a total of {{INRConvert|39.8|m}}. Ticket sales started to fall from Monday onward with a collection of {{INRConvert|5.7|m}}, followed by {{INRConvert|5.3|m}} on Tuesday, making a total of {{INRConvert|58|m}}.{{cite web|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.in/raman-raghav-2-0-box-office-collection-nawazuddin-vicky-starrer-earns-rs-5-crore-5-days-684897|title='Raman Raghav 2.0' box office collection: Nawazuddin-Vicky starrer earns Rs. 5 crore in 5 days|last=Mehta|first=Ankita|publisher=International Business Times|date=29 June 2016|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011021949/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/raman-raghav-2-0-box-office-collection-nawazuddin-vicky-starrer-earns-rs-5-crore-5-days-684897|archivedate=11 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} ''Raman Raghav 2.0'' earned {{INRConvert|67.4|m}} in its 10-day theatrical run.{{cite web|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.in/box-office-collection-udta-punjab-raman-raghav-2-0-record-slow-week-sardaarji-2-doing-685556|title=Box office collection: 'Udta Punjab' and 'Raman Raghav 2.0' record a slow week; 'Sardaarji 2' doing well worldwide|last=Mehta|first=Ankita|publisher=International Business Times|date=5 July 2016|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170919222929/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/box-office-collection-udta-punjab-raman-raghav-2-0-record-slow-week-sardaarji-2-doing-685556|archivedate=19 September 2017|df=dmy-all}} At the end of its theatrical run, the film earned a total box-office collection of {{INRConvert|70|m}}. === Awards === Siddiqui received the Best Actor award at the [[Asia Pacific Screen Awards]].{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/nawazuddin-siddiqui-manoj-bajpayee-honoured-at-asia-pacific-screen-awards-4393574/|title=Nawazuddin Siddiqui, Manoj Bajpayee honoured at Asia Pacific Screen Awards|work=The Indian Express|date=24 November 2016|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127125953/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/nawazuddin-siddiqui-manoj-bajpayee-honoured-at-asia-pacific-screen-awards-4393574/|archivedate=27 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} Kashyap garnered the Europe Fantastic Film Festivals Federation Asian Award at the Bucheon International Fantastic Film Festival.{{cite web|url=https://www.bifan.kr/eng/bifan/history_jury.asp?sc_year=2016|title=Awards (2016)|publisher=Bucheon International Fantastic Film Festival|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411075144/https://www.bifan.kr/eng/bifan/history_jury.asp?sc_year=2016|archivedate=11 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} Kashyap, along with Siddiqui and Bala received the official jury prizes at the [[Fancine|Fantastic Film Festival of the University of Málaga]].{{cite web|url=http://externos.uma.es/cultura/fancine/2016/index.php/2016/11/21/palmares-de-la-26-edicion-de-fancine/|title=Palmarés de la 26 edición de Fancine|publisher=Fantastic Film Festival of the University of Málaga|language=French|accessdate=11 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170710042943/http://externos.uma.es/cultura/fancine/2016/index.php/2016/11/21/palmares-de-la-26-edicion-de-fancine/|archivedate=10 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} == See also == * ''[[The Stoneman Murders]]'' == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=tt5662932}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=raman_raghav_20|title=Raman Raghav 2.0}} {{Anurag Kashyap}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Indian thriller films]] [[Category:Hindi-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Anurag Kashyap]] revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=July 2014}} {{Notability|1=Music|date=July 2014}} The '''Sonic Mook Experiment''' is a music enterprise overseen by [[Sean McLusky]] which encompasses a club night and several albums.
The club claims that ''"like many great clubs in that it was about good music, drugs, scoop live performances, attractive fashionable people and quirky fad-inspiring outfits"''.
The first Sonic Mook Experiment was held at a venue called The Wheel in [[Holborn]] in early 1997, taking place alongside [[Heavenly Records|Heavenly Records']] Social. The emphasis was very much on eclecticism, with [[Sigue Sigue Sputnik]] playing against a backdrop of guitar, beats and hip hop music. The club's move to 333 in [[Shoreditch]] saw live bands like [[Clinic (band)|Clinic]], [[Asian Dub Foundation]] and [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]] play, as well as boundary-breaking underground electronic music, such as [[Jonathan Saul Kane|J Saul Kane]], [[Jerry Dammers]] and [[Andrew Weatherall]]. The club segued from the collision of electronic and indie in the late 90s into the more pronounced rock and roll of 2001 onwards.
In early 2002, Sonic Mook Relocated to the 93 Feet East club on [[Brick Lane]] in the East End of London. There it produced exclusive first live performances in London from bands like the [[New York City]] punk-funk outfit [[The Rapture (band)|The Rapture]].
In June 2002, it staged an event at the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] on The Mall in London, during the Queen's [[Golden Jubilee]]. The event, held over four days, launched the second CD in the ''Future Rock & Roll'' series. The new album featured 25 tracks from some of the hottest new bands around, many for the first time on CD. Capturing the energy and attitude of the club night that spawned it and the nascent rock and roll scene in London and New York, it included tracks from [[The Eighties Matchbox B-Line Disaster]], [[Liars (band)|The Liars]], [[The Martini Henry Rifles]], [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]], Some Product by Anne McCloy, [[Fat Truckers]], and [[The Buff Medways]]. Several disturbances during the festival saw armed police escorting attendees away during the high security Jubilee celebrations nearby.
After a hiatus, aside from occasional get-togethers, the night returned to 333, more recently the Dogstar in [[Brixton]].
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051210173241/http://www.sonicmook.co.uk/ Official site (now offline)]
[[Category:Music events]]

{{italic title}} '''''Wallenberg''''' is an [[opera]] by the Estonian [[composer]] [[Erkki-Sven Tüür]] to a [[libretto]] by [[:de:Lutz Hübner|Lutz Hübner]]. The plot is developed from events in [[Raoul Wallenberg]]'s personal life. The opera premiered at the [[Opernhaus Dortmund]] on May 5, 2001.[http://www.omm.de/veranstaltungen/musiktheater20002001/DO-wallenberg.html Die Nazis erobern Disneyland][http://www.operundtanz.de/archiv/2001/04/bericht-dortmund.shtml Realität und Fiktion] It premiered at the [[Estonian National Opera]] on June 1, 2007, directed by [[Dmitry Bertman]].[http://www.emic.ee/performances-of-erkki-sven-tuurs-opera--wallenberg--in-germany Performances of Erkki-Svne Tüü's opera ''Wallenberg'' in Germany][http://www.opera.ee/en/lavastus/wallenberg/ ''Wallenberg'' at Estonian National Opera][http://www.musicweb-international.com/sandH/2009/jan-jun09/wallenberg0506.htm ''Wallenberg''. International Opera Review] == Roles == {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast, 5 May 2001
Conductor: [[Alexander Rumpf]] |- |[[Raoul Wallenberg]], Swedish diplomat, rescuer tens of thousands Jews |[[bass-baritone]] | [[:fi:Hannu Niemelä|Hannu Niemelä]] |- |[[Adolf Eichmann]], German Nazi SS-Obersturmbannführer |[[Bass (voice type)|bass]] | Thomas Mehnert |- |Wallenberg second |[[tenor]] | Hannes Brock |- |[[Ronald Reagan]], the 40th President of the United States |[[baritone]] | Andreas Becker |- |[[Jacob Wallenberg]], Swedish banker, a member of the [[Wallenberg family]] |tenor | Michael-Silvan Scheel |- |American General |bass-bariton | Bernhard Modes |- |American Soldier |baritone | Johannes Knecht |- |German Officer |baritone | Andreas Becker |- |The First Survivor |[[mezzo-soprano]] | Margarita Malevska |- |The Second Survivor |tenor | Jae-Seok Lee |- |The Third Survivor |bass | Hanno Kreft |- |The First Guest |tenor | Michael-Silvan Scheel |- |The Second Guest |bass-bariton | Bernhard Modes |- |The Third Guest |bariton | Hans-Werner Trede |- |The First Diplomat |[[soprano]] | Gundula Schneider |- |The Second Diplomat |mezzo-soprano | Andrea Rieche |- |The Third Diplomat |[[contralto]] | Karin Robben |- |Dame |mezzo-soprano | Susan Benkin |- |Woman |soprano | Barbara Dobrzanska |- |The First Russian Officer |tenor | Martin Müller-Görgner |- |The Second Russian Officer |tenor | Darius Scheliga |- |The Three Gulag Prisoners |bariton, bass, bariton | Lothar Becher
Thomas Günzler
Georg Kirketerp |- |Jews, guests, GULag's prisoners[http://www.erkkisven.com/worklist-and-reviews/works-for-the-stage ''Wallenberg'' at the official site of Erkki-Sven Tüür][http://www.erpmusic.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=212&Itemid=246 ''Wallenberg''. Performers][http://www.staatstheater.karlsruhe.de/programm/besetzung/1163/ Besetzung (Roles)] | Choir | Choir of Theater Dortmund |} == Synopsis == === Act 1 === 1. Prologue. Nameless Voices asked questions — after Wallenberg's deeds and his fate: "Do we doing honour a living person or a dead person?" 2. The Conference I. Sweden in 1944. A reception. Three guests whispering about the professional misses of the young Wallenberg. But three diplomats give his life new meaning. You go to entrust your with the mission to Hungary, to save "as many Jews as possible". The warnings of a lady, not to be exploited for foreign targets, can not stop Wallenberg. After initial hesitation, he accepts the order. 3. Railway Station I. Hungary 1944. Wallenberg must helplessly watch as running a German officers and his men the order of the Nazi regime, "thousands of Jews every day ..." 4. The Plan I Wallenberg takes a promising tactic: Swedish protective passports "Will make Jews like Sweden" and keep them from being deported. 5. Railway Station II Wallenberg again meets the German officer. He manages to rescue some people from the brutality of the Nazis "Passport hits gun" 6. The rescued. A group of saved of Wallenberg shows for the fragility of their destiny in mind: "Life is not be more than dead." Wallenberg realizes that there is every life is individual and very expensive. 7. The Plan II Wallenberg is struggling with self-reproach: "Not enough! I not act enough!" He decides to face the evil. 8. Eichmann I. Wallenberg met Adolf Eichmann. He confronted him with the goal of his saving deeds. But Eichmann was a bureaucrat and behaves like a gentleman. With relish, he shows the Wallenberg's limits of its possibilities in mind. And even the diplomats start to doubt the mission of Wallenberg. The time he runs away. 9. Station III. Wallenberg throws himself into the work. But an encounter with a woman he has rescued leaves him utterly disappointed in the meaning of his deeds. She returns her protective passport to Wallenberg — so unbearably she feels the guilt to have survived "by chance". 10. The Plan III. Wallenberg gets in panics about the immensity of his task. Once again, he encounters a woman who advises him to pause and reflect on itself. 11. The death march. Hungary, January, 1945 — "And He made me pass by them round about, and lo! they were exceedingly many on the surface of the valley, and lo! they were exceedingly dry." Old testament, [[Book of Ezekiel]] (37, 2).[http://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/16135 Yechezkel - Ezekiel - Chapter 37] The last time Eichmann demonstrates his superiority. The war ended. Wallenberg hopes for a fresh start. But at the moment of the freeing appear two Russian soldiers. They summon Raoul Wallenberg for the questioning ...[http://www.staatstheater.karlsruhe.de/media/programmheft/Programmheft_WALLENBERG_01.pdf Staatstheater Karlsruhe 2011/12. Program booklet No. 70.] === Act 2 === 12. SMERSH. Moscow, 1945. Wallenberg has got into the clutches of SMERSH, the Russian counter-intelligence. He is held prisoner in the infamous Moscow state prison Lubjanka. Two Russian officers denied knowing the whereabouts of Wallenberg: "We do not have him!" 13. The Conference II Three diplomats visited Wallenberg. But instead of freeing him, they tell him about his new mission: "Only half of the war is now won". As a hero he was caught in the Cold War and more useful than a free man. 14. Gulag I. Kolyma, uncertain time. Wallenberg is subjected to a brutal interrogation. Meanwhile, the inmates of the Gulag tell each other about their fate and the arbitrariness of the judicial authorities. There are circulating rumors contradictory: "The Swede is alive. The Swede is dead." 15. Gulag II Three Gulag prisoners believes Wallenberg recognizable as one of their fellow prisoners. His survival also maintains their hope. But Wallenberg not remember — neither of his time in the camp, even to his own identity. "There is a hole in my head". The other prisoners reacted with aggression to Wallenberg refusal to accept his role as savior. Intermezzo. Traces of Wallenberg are erased. 16. The struggle. From Nothing appears Wallenberg 2, a masterful bugbear of the acts complained of Wallenberg, "I'm your hero, you will not get rid of me." 17. Eichmann II Eichmann is preparing for the penalty. For the last time he taunted Wallenberg: While he was a "clean finish" would be granted, would fail a saving Wallenberg's death. Eichmann is hanged. 18. The conference III. Wallenberg hopes explanations to find about his destiny with three diplomats. But these dismiss his doubts about the sense of the history as "child questions". Wallenberg silent. But his "For which?" does not remain in entirety unanswered. Two survivors remembers their rescue. 19. Wallenberg circus. Future generations takes the heritage of Raoul Wallenberg. The public sings praises heroism. And Ronald Reagan appointed him an honorary citizen of the United States. Wallenberg 2 takes the honors of the crowd with pride: "No trace of a doubt!" The voice of a woman remembers the dead. == Awards == * Cultural Prize of the Republic of Estonia * Annual Award of Estonian Theatre in the category of musical stagings. == Literatur == * Klaus Stübler und Christine Wolf: ''Harenbergs Komponistenlexikon.'' Harenberg Lexikon Verlag, Dortmund 2001, {{ISBN|3-611-00978-4}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.opera.ee/en/lavastus/wallenberg/ ''Wallenberg'' at the Estonian National Opera] * [http://www.sirp.ee/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1883:erkki-sven-t-ri-ooper-wallenberg&catid=5:muusika&Itemid=12&issue=3162 Opera ''Wallenberg'' in Estonia] (in Estonian) * [http://www.pz-news.de/kultur_artikel,-Premiere-der-Oper-Wallenberg-am-Badischen-Staatstheater-Karlsruhe-_arid,355348.html Premiere der Oper ''Wallenberg'' am Badischen Staatstheater Karlsruhe] (in German) * [http://www.staatstheater.karlsruhe.de/programm/info/1163/ Opera ''Wallenberg''] in [[Badisches Staatstheater Karlsruhe]] (in German) * [http://www.badische-zeitung.de/theater-rezensionen/der-schindler-von-budapest--61441405.html "Der Schindler von Budapest". Die Oper ''Wallenberg'' des Esten Erkki-Sven Tüür in Karlsruhe.] (in German) * [http://www.estemb.de/kultur_und_galerie/aid-1217 Oper ''Wallenberg'' in Karlsruhe] (in German) * [https://www.welt.de/regionales/stuttgart/article108125922/Kratzer-inszeniert-Wallenberg-im-Staatstheater.html Kratzer inszeniert ''Wallenberg'' im Staatstheater] (in German) [[Category:German-language operas]] [[Category:Music dramas]] [[Category:2001 operas]] [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Operas based on real people]] [[Category:Operas set in the 20th century]] [[Category:Operas set in Sweden]] [[Category:Operas set in Germany]] [[Category:Operas set in Hungary]] [[Category:Operas set in Russia]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Raoul Wallenberg]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Adolf Eichmann]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Ronald Reagan]]

revision.text:
A '''wine fault''' or '''defect''' is an unpleasant characteristic of a [[wine]] often resulting from poor [[winemaking]] practices or [[storage conditions (wine)|storage conditions]], and leading to '''wine spoilage'''. Many of the compounds that cause wine faults are already naturally present in wine but at insufficient concentrations to be of issue. In fact, depending on [[perception]], these concentrations may impart positive characters to the wine. However, when the concentration of these compounds greatly exceeds the [[sensory threshold]], they replace or obscure the [[flavor]]s and [[aromas (wine)|aromas]] that the wine should be expressing (or that the winemaker wants the wine to express). Ultimately the quality of the wine is reduced, making it less appealing and sometimes undrinkable.<ref name="Baldy pg 37-39, et al">M. Baldy ''"The University Wine Course" Third Edition pgs 37-39, 69-80, 134-140 The Wine Appreciation Guild 2009 {{ISBN|0-932664-69-5}}</ref>
There are many causes for the perception in wine faults, including poor [[hygiene]] at the winery, excessive or insufficient exposure of the wine to [[oxygen]], excessive or insufficient exposure of the wine to [[sulphur]], overextended [[maceration (wine)|maceration]] of the wine either pre- or post-[[Fermentation (wine)|fermentation]], faulty [[fining, filtering and stabilization of the wine]], the use of dirty [[oak barrels]], over-extended barrel aging and the use of poor quality corks. Outside of the winery, other factors within the control of the retailer or end user of the wine can contribute to the perception of flaws in the wine. These include poor [[storage of the wine]] that exposes it to excessive heat and temperature fluctuations as well as the use of dirty [[stemware]] during [[wine tasting]] that can introduce materials or aromas to what was previously a clean and fault-free wine.<ref name="Baldy pg 37-39, et al"/><ref name="Bird pg 31-82, et al">D. Bird ''"Understanding Wine Technology"'' pg 31-82, 155-184, 202-222 DBQA Publishing 2005 {{ISBN|1-891267-91-4}}</ref>
==Differences between flaws and faults== In wine tasting, there is a big distinction made between what is considered a ''flaw'' and a ''fault''. Wine flaws are minor attributes that depart from what are perceived as normal wine characteristics. These include excessive [[sulfur dioxide]], [[volatile acidity]], ''[[Brettanomyces]]'' or "Brett aromas" and [[diacetyl]] or buttery aromas. The amount to which these aromas or attributes become excessive is dependent on the particular tastes and [[recognition threshold]] of the wine taster. Generally, a wine exhibiting these qualities is still considered drinkable by most people. However, some flaws such as volatile acidity and ''Brettanomyces'' can be considered a fault when they are in such an excess that they overwhelm other components of the wine. Wine faults are generally major attributes that make a wine undrinkable to most wine tasters. Examples of wine faults include [[acetaldehyde]] (except when purposely induced in wines like [[Sherry]] and [[Rancio]]), [[ethyl acetate]] and [[cork taint]].<ref name="Baldy pg 37-39, et al"/>
==Detecting faults in wine tasting== The vast majority of wine faults are detected by the nose and the distinctive aromas that they give off. However, the presence of some wine faults can be detected by visual and taste perceptions. For example, premature oxidation can be noticed by the yellowing and [[Browning in red wine|browning]] of the [[wine's color]]. The sign of gas bubbles in wines that are not meant to be [[sparkling (wine)|sparkling]] can be a sign of [[Fermentation (wine)|refermentation]] or [[malolactic fermentation]] happening in the bottle. Unusual breaks in the color of the wine could be a sign of excessive [[copper]], [[iron]] or [[proteins]] that were not removed during fining or filtering. A wine with an unusual color for its variety or wine region could be a sign of excessive or insufficient maceration as well as poor temperature controls during fermentation. Tactile clues of potential wine faults include the burning, acidic taste associated with [[volatile acidity]] that can make a wine seem out of balance.<ref name="Baldy pg 37-39, et al"/><ref name="Bird pg 31-82, et al"/>
{| |- style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0;" ||'''Wine fault''' ||'''Characteristics''' |- | [[Acetaldehyde]]||Smell of roasted nuts or dried out straw. Commonly associated with Sherries where these aromas are considered acceptable |- | [[Amyl-acetate]]||Smell of "fake" candy banana flavoring |- | [[Brettanomyces]]||Smell of barnyards, fecal and gamey horse aromas |- | [[Cork taint]]||Smell of a damp basement, wet cardboard or newspapers and mushrooms |- | [[Butyric acid]]||Smell of rancid butter |- | [[Ethyl acetate]]||Smell of vinegar, paint thinner and nail polish remover |- | [[Hydrogen sulfide]]||Smell of rotten eggs or garlic that has gone bad |- | [[Iodine]]||Smell of moldy grapes |- | [[Lactic acid bacteria]]||Smell of sauerkraut |- | [[Mercaptans]]||Smell of burnt garlic or onion |- | [[Oxidation]]||Smell of cooked fruit and walnuts. Also detectable visually by premature browning or yellowing of the wine |- | [[Sorbic acid]] plus [[lactic acid bacteria]]||Smell of crushed [[geranium]] leaves |- | [[Sulfur dioxide]]||Smell of burnt matches. Can also come across as a pricking sensation in the nose. |}
==Oxidation== {{See also|Premature oxidation}} The [[oxidation]] of wine is perhaps the most common of wine faults, as the presence of [[oxygen]] and a [[catalyst]] are the only requirements for the process to occur. Oxidation can occur throughout the winemaking process, and even after the wine has been bottled. [[Anthocyanin]]s, [[catechin]]s, epicatechins and other [[Phenolic content in wine|phenols]] present in wine are those most easily oxidised,<ref name=duToitW>duToit, W.J. (2005). [http://www.wynboer.co.za/recentarticles/200508oxygen.php3 Oxygen in winemaking: Part I]. WineLand. URL accessed on 2 April 2006.</ref> which leads to a loss of colour, flavour and aroma - sometimes referred to as ''flattening''. In most cases compounds such as [[sulfur dioxide]] or [[erythorbic acid]] are added to wine by winemakers, which protect the wine from oxidation and also bind with some of the oxidation products to reduce their organoleptic effect.<ref name=goode>Goode, Jamie (05/16/05). [http://www.wineint.com/storyprint.asp?sc=1810 Oxidation (link is dead)]. Wine International. URL accessed on 2 April 2006.</ref> Apart from phenolic oxidation, the [[ethanol]] present within wine can also be oxidised into other compounds responsible for flavour and aroma taints.
[[File:Oxidation of ethanol.svg|center|thumb|500px|The oxidation of ethanol]]
===Acetaldehyde=== [[Acetaldehyde]] is an intermediate product of [[Yeast in winemaking|yeast]] [[fermentation (wine)|fermentation]]; however, it is more commonly associated with [[ethanol]] [[oxidation]] catalysed by the enzyme [[alcohol dehydrogenase|ethanol dehydrogenase]]. Acetaldehyde production is also associated with the presence of surface film forming yeasts and bacteria, such as [[acetic acid bacteria]], which form the compound by the [[decarboxylation]] of [[pyruvate]]. The [[sensory threshold]] for acetaldehyde is 100-125 [[Micrograms|mg]]/[[litre|L]]. Beyond this level it imparts a ''[[sherry]]'' type character to the wine which can also be described as ''green apple'', ''sour'' and ''metallic''. Acetaldehyde [[Substance intoxication|intoxication]] is also implicated in [[hangover]]s.
===Acetic acid=== [[Acetic acid]] in wine, often referred to as volatile acidity (VA) or ''vinegar taint'', can be contributed by many wine spoilage [[yeasts]] and [[bacteria]]. This can be from either a [[by-product]] of fermentation, or due to the spoilage of finished wine. Acetic acid bacteria, such as those from the genera ''[[Acetobacter]]'' and ''[[Gluconobacter]]'' produce high levels of acetic acid. The [[sensory threshold]] for acetic acid in wine is >700 mg/L, with concentrations greater than 1.2-1.3 g/L becoming unpleasant.
There are different opinions as to what level of volatile acidity is appropriate for higher quality wine. Although too high a concentration is sure to leave an undesirable, 'vinegar' tasting wine, some wine's acetic acid levels are developed to create a more 'complex', desirable taste.<ref>[http://www.wineint.com/story.asp?storyCode=1908 Volatile Acidity] - great article from [[Wine & Spirit]] mag</ref> The renowned 1947 [[Château Cheval Blanc|Cheval Blanc]] is widely recognized to contain high levels of volatile acidity.
[[Ethyl acetate]] is formed in wine by the [[esterification]] of ethanol and acetic acid. Therefore, wines with high acetic acid levels are more likely to see ethyl acetate formation, but the compound does not contribute to the volatile acidity. It is a common microbial fault produced by [[wine spoilage yeast]]s, particularly ''[[Pichia anomala]]'' or ''[[Kloeckera apiculata]]''. High levels of ethyl acetate are also produced by [[lactic acid bacteria]] and [[acetic acid bacteria]].
==Sulfur compounds== [[Sulfur]] is used as an [[food additive|additive]] throughout the winemaking process, primarily to stop oxidation as mentioned above but also as [[antimicrobial]] agent. When managed properly in wine, its presence there is often undetected, however when used recklessly it can contribute to flavour and aroma taints which are very volatile and potent. Sulfur compounds typically have low sensory thresholds.
===Sulfur dioxide=== [[File:Sulfur-dioxide-2D.svg|right|150px|Sulfur dioxide]] [[Sulfur dioxide]] is a common wine additive, used for its [[antioxidant]] and [[preservative]] properties. When its use is not managed well it can be overadded, with its perception in wine reminiscent of ''matchsticks'', ''burnt rubber'', or ''mothballs''. Wines such as these are often termed ''sulfitic''.
===Hydrogen sulfide=== [[File:Hydrogen-sulfide-2D-dimensions.svg|right|150px|Hydrogen sulfide]] [[Hydrogen sulfide]] (H<sub>2</sub>S) is generally thought to be a metabolic by-product of yeast fermentation in [[Yeast assimilable nitrogen|nitrogen limited environments]]. It is formed when yeast ferments via the [[sulfate reduction pathway]]. Fermenting wine is often supplemented with [[diammonium phosphate]] (DAP) as a nitrogen source to prevent H<sub>2</sub>S formation. The sensory threshold for hydrogen sulfide is 8-10 μg/L, with levels above this imparting a distinct ''rotten egg'' aroma to the wine. Hydrogen sulfide can further react with wine compounds to form mercaptans and [[disulfide]]s.
===Mercaptans=== [[File:Ethanethiol2.svg|thumb|right|150px|[[ethanethiol|ethyl mercaptan]]]] [[Mercaptans]] (thiols) are produced in wine by the reaction of hydrogen sulfide with other wine components such as ethanol. They can be formed if finished wine is allowed prolonged contact with the [[lees (fermentation)|lees]]. This can be prevented by [[racking]] the wine. Mercaptans have a very low sensory threshold, around 1.5 [[Micrograms|µg]]/[[litre|L]],<ref name=ETS1>[http://www.etslabs.com/pagetemplate/blank.asp?pageid=350 Technical Bulletin - Sulfides in Wine]. ETS Laboratories. URL accessed on 12 March 2006.</ref> with levels above causing ''onion'', ''rubber'', and ''skunk'' type odours. Note that dimethyl disulfide is formed from the oxidation of methyl mercaptan.
===Dimethyl sulfide=== [[File:dimethyl sulfide structure.svg|right|140px|Dimethyl sulfide]] [[Dimethyl sulfide]] (DMS) is naturally present in most wines, probably from the breakdown of sulfur containing amino acids. Like ethyl acetate, levels of DMS below the sensory threshold can have a positive effect on flavour, contributing to ''fruityness'', ''fullness'', and ''complexity''. Levels above the sensory threshold of >30 µg/L in white wines and >50 µg/L for red wines, give the wine characteristics of ''cooked cabbage'', ''canned corn'', ''asparagus'' or ''truffles''.
==Environmental==
===Cork taint=== [[File:2,4,6-Trichloroanisole.svg|120px|right|thumb|2,4,6-trichloroanisole]] {{Main article|Cork taint}} Cork taint is a wine fault mostly attributed to the compound [[2,4,6-trichloroanisole]] (TCA), although other compounds such as [[guaiacol]], [[geosmin]], [[2-methylisoborneol]], [[1-Octen-3-ol|1-octen-3-ol]], [[1-octen-3-one]], [[2,3,4,6-tetrachloroanisole]], [[pentachloroanisole]], and [[2,4,6-tribromoanisole]] are also thought to be involved.<ref name=LaMar>LaMar, Jim (09/25/02). [http://www.winepros.org/wine101/vincyc-tca.htm Cork Taint]. URL accessed on 12 March 2006.</ref> TCA most likely originates as a [[metabolite]] of [[mould]] growth on [[chlorine]]-bleached wine corks and barrels. It causes ''earthy'', ''mouldy'', and ''musty'' aromas in wine that easily mask the natural fruit aromas, making the wine very unappealing. Wines in this state are often described as ''"corked"''. As cork taint has gained a wide reputation as a wine fault, other faults are often mistakenly attributed to it.
===Heat damage=== Heat damaged wines are often casually referred to as ''cooked'', which suggests how heat can affect a wine. They are also known as '''maderized''' wine, from [[Madeira wine]], which is intentionally exposed to heat. The ideal storage temperature for wine is generally accepted to be 13 °C (55 °F). Wines that are stored at temperatures greatly higher than this will experience an increased aging rate. Wines exposed to extreme temperatures will [[thermal expansion|thermally expand]], and may even push up between the cork and bottle and leak from the top. When opening a bottle of wine, if a trace of wine is visible along the length of the cork, the cork is partially pushed out of the bottle, or wine is visible on the top of the cork while it is still in the bottle, it has most likely been heat damaged. Heat damaged wines often become oxidized, and red wines may take on a brick color.
Even if the temperatures do not reach extremes, temperature variation alone can also damage bottled wine through oxidation. All corks allow some leakage of air (hence old wines become increasingly oxidized), and temperature fluctuations will vary the pressure differential between the inside and outside of the bottle and will act to "pump" air into the bottle at a faster rate than will occur at any temperature strictly maintained.
Reputedly, heat damage is the most widespread and common problem found in wines. It often goes unnoticed because of the prevalence of the problem, consumers don't know it's possible, and most often would just chalk the problem up to poor quality, or other factors.
===Lightstrike=== Lightstruck wines are those that have had excessive exposure to [[ultraviolet]] light, particularly in the range 325 to 450 nm.<ref name=drouhin>Drouhin, R.J. (01/23/98) [http://www.drouhin.com/wineviti/glasses.html Bottle Glass]. URL Accessed 3 April 2006</ref> Very delicate wines, such as [[Champagne (wine)|Champagne]]s, are generally worst affected, with the fault causing a ''wet cardboard'' or ''wet wool'' type flavour and aroma. Red wines rarely become lightstruck because of the phenolic compounds present within the wine that protect it. Lightstrike is thought to be caused by sulfur compounds such as [[dimethyl sulfide]]. In France lightstrike is known as "''goût de lumière''", which translates to ''a taste of light''. The fault explains why wines are generally bottled in coloured glass, which blocks the ultraviolet light, and why wine should be stored in dark environments.
===Ladybird (pyrazine) taint=== Some insects present in the grapes at harvest inevitably end up in the press and for the most part are inoffensive. Others, notably the [[Harmonia axyridis|Asian lady beetle]], release unpleasant smelling nitrogen heterocycles as a defensive mechanism when disturbed. In sufficient quantities these can affect the wine's odor and taste. With an olfactory detection threshold of a few ppb, the principal active compound is [[isopropyl methoxy pyrazine]] - this molecule is perceived as rancid [[peanut butter]], bitter and herbal, green [[bell pepper]], or urine like. This is also a naturally occurring compound in Sauvignon grapes and so [[pyrazine]] taint has been known to make [[Riesling]]s taste like [[Sauvignon blanc]]{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}.
==Microbiological==
===''Brettanomyces'' (''Dekkera'')=== {{Main article|Brettanomyces}} The yeast ''[[Brettanomyces]]'' produces an array of [[metabolite]]s when growing in wine, some of which are volatile [[Phenolic content in wine|phenol]]ic compounds. Together these compounds are often referred to as ''phenolic taint'', ''"Brettanomyces character"'', or simply "Brett". The main constituents are listed below, with their sensory threshold and common sensory descriptors: *'''[[4-ethylphenol]]''' (>140 µg/L): Band-aids, barnyard, horse stable, antiseptic *'''[[4-ethylguaiacol]]''' (>600 µg/L): Bacon, spice, cloves, smoky *'''[[3-Methylbutanoic acid|isovaleric acid]]''': Sweaty, cheese, rancidity
===Geosmin=== [[File:Geosmin minus acsv.svg|130px|right]] [[Geosmin]] is a compound with a very distinct ''earthy'', ''musty'', ''beetroot'', even ''turnip'' flavour and aroma and has an extremely low sensory threshold of down to 10 parts per trillion. Its presence in wine is usually derived as metabolite from the growth of filamentous [[Actinobacteria|actinomycetes]] such as ''[[Streptomyces]]'', and [[mold|mould]]s such as ''[[Botrytis cinerea]]'' and ''Penicillium expansum'', on grapes. Wines affected by but not attributed to geosmins are often thought to have earthy properties due to [[terroir]].<ref name=kennel>Kennel, Florence (14/12/05). [http://www.decanter.com/news/60674.html Bordeaux boffin solves geosmin conundrum]. Decanter.com. URL accessed on 2 April 2006.</ref> The geosmin fault occurs worldwide and has been found in recent vintages of red wines from [[Beaujolais]], [[Bordeaux]], [[Burgundy wine|Burgundy]] and the [[Loire]] in France. Geosmin is also thought to be a contributing factor in [[cork taint]].
===Lactic acid bacteria=== {{Main article|Malolactic_fermentation#Wine_faults}} [[Lactic acid bacteria]] have a useful role in winemaking converting [[malic acid]] to lactic acid in [[malolactic fermentation]]. However, after this function has completed, the bacteria may still be present within the wine, where they can metabolise other compounds and produce wine faults. Wines that have not undergone malolactic fermentation may be contaminated with lactic acid bacteria, leading to refermentation of the wine with it becoming [[turbidity|turbid]], ''swampy'', and slightly [[effervescence|effervescent]] or ''spritzy''. This can be avoided by sterile filtering wine directly before bottling. Lactic acid bacteria can also be responsible for other wine faults such as those below.
====Bitterness taint==== [[File:Acrolein-skeletal.png|right|120px|thumb|Acrolein]] Bitterness taint or ''amertume'' is rather uncommon and is produced by certain strains of bacteria from the genera ''[[Pediococcus]]'', ''[[Lactobacillus]]'', and ''[[Oenococcus]]''. It begins by the degradation of [[glycerol]], a compound naturally found in wine at levels of 5-8 g/L, via a [[dehydratase]] enzyme to ''3-hydroxypropionaldehyde''. During ageing this is further dehydrated to [[acrolein]] which reacts with the [[anthocyanin]]s and other phenols present within the wine to form the taint.<ref name=duToitM>duToit, M., Pretorius, I.S. (2000). “Microbial spoilage and preservation of wine: Using weapons from nature's own arsenal - A review”. South African Journal of Enology and Viticulture 21: 74-96.</ref> As red wines contain high levels of anthocyanins they are generally more susceptible.
====Diacetyl==== [[File:diacetyl structure.svg|130px|right|thumb|Diacetyl]] [[Diacetyl]] in wine is produced by [[lactic acid bacteria]], mainly ''[[Oenococcus oeni]]''. In low levels it can impart positive ''nutty'' or ''caramel'' characters, however at levels above 5 mg/L it creates an intense ''buttery'' or ''[[butterscotch]]'' flavour, where it is perceived as a flaw. The sensory threshold for the compound can vary depending on the levels of certain wine components, such as sulfur dioxide. It can be produced as a metabolite of [[citric acid]] when all of the [[malic acid]] has been consumed. Diacetyl rarely taints wine to levels where it becomes undrinkable.<ref name=gibson>Gibson, George; Farkas, Mike [http://www.bcawa.ca/winemaking/flaws.htm Flaws and Faults in Wine]. URL accessed on 12 March 2006.</ref>
====Geranium taint==== [[File:2-ethoxy-3,5-hexadiene.svg|200px|right|thumb|2-ethoxy-3,5-hexadiene]] Geranium taint, as the name suggests, is a flavour and aroma taint in wine reminiscent of [[pelargonium|geranium]] leaves. The compound responsible is ''[[2-ethoxyhexa-3,5-diene]]'', which has a low sensory threshold concentration of 1 ng/L.<ref name=huhn>Hühn, T; Sponholz, W.R. and Pulver, D. (1999). [http://www.beverages.ch/service/Microorganisms.PDF The influence of microorganisms in winemaking]. (PDF) URL accessed on 2 April 2006.</ref> In wine it is formed during the [[metabolism]] of [[potassium sorbate]] by [[lactic acid bacteria]]. Potassium sorbate is sometimes added to wine as a [[preservative]] against yeast, however its use is generally kept to a minimum due to the possibility of the taint developing. The production of the taint begins with the conversion of [[sorbic acid]] to the alcohol ''[[sorbinol]]''. The alcohol is then [[isomerisation|isomerised]] in the presence of acid to ''[[3,5-hexadiene-2-ol]]'', which is then esterified with ethanol to form ''[[2-ethoxy-3,5-hexadiene]]''.<ref name=huhn/> As ethanol is necessary for the conversion, the geranium taint is not usually found in [[must]].
====Mannitol==== [[File:Mannitol structure.png|150px|thumb|right|Mannitol]] [[Mannitol]] is a [[sugar alcohol]], and in wine it is produced by [[heterofermentative]] lactic acid bacteria, such as ''[[Lactobacillus brevis]]'', by the [[redox|reduction]] of [[fructose]]. Its perception is often complicated as it generally exists in wine alongside other faults, but it is usually described as [[viscous]], [[ester]]-like combined with a sweet and irritating finish.<ref name=duToitM/> Mannitol is usually produced in wines that undergo malolactic fermentation with a high level of [[residual sugar]]s still present. Expert winemakers oftentimes add small amounts of sulfur dioxide during the crushing step to reduce early bacterial growth.
====Ropiness==== Ropiness is manifested as an increase in [[viscosity]] and a ''slimey'' or ''fatty'' mouthfeel of a wine. In France the fault is known as "''graisse''", which translates to ''fat''. The problem stems from the production of [[dextrin]]s and [[polysaccharide]]s by certain lactic acid bacteria, particularly of the genera ''[[Leuconostoc]]'' and ''[[Pediococcus]]''.
===Mousiness=== [[File:1-(3,4,5,6-tetrahydropyridin-2-yl)-ethanone.svg|right|thumb|150px|''2-acetyl-3,4,5,6-<br />tetrahydropyridine'']] Mousiness is a wine fault most often attributed to ''Brettanomyces'' but can also originate from the [[lactic acid bacteria]] ''[[Lactobacillus brevis]]'', ''[[Lactobacillus fermentum]]'', and ''[[Lactobacillus hilgardii]],''<ref name=duToitM/> and hence can occur in [[malolactic fermentation]]. The compounds responsible are [[lysine]] derivatives, mainly; *[[2-acetyl-3,4,5,6-tetrahydropyridine]] *[[2-acetyl-1,4,5,6-tetrahydropyridine]] *[[2-ethyltetrahydropyridine]]<ref name=marias>Marais, Johann [http://www.wynboer.co.za/recentarticles/0299nitrogen.php3 Flavourful nitrogen containing wine constituents] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060928171657/http://www.wynboer.co.za/recentarticles/0299nitrogen.php3 |date=2006-09-28 }}. Wynboer. URL accessed on 12 March 2006.</ref> *[[2-acetyl-1-pyrrolene]] The taints are not volatile at the [[pH]] of wine, and therefore not obvious as an aroma. However, when mixed with the slightly basic pH of saliva they can become very apparent on the palate,<ref name=gawell>Gawell, Richard [http://www.aromadictionary.com/articles/mousey_article.html Somellier, A Mouse Must Have Wee'd in My Wine!]. aromadictionary.com. URL accessed on 12 March 2006.</ref> especially at the back of the mouth, as ''mouse cage'' or ''mouse urine''.
=== Refermentation === Refermentation, sometimes called [[secondary fermentation (wine)|secondary fermentation]], is caused by yeasts refermenting the [[residual sugar]] present within bottled wine. It occurs when [[sweetness of wine|sweet wines]] are bottled in non-[[Asepsis|sterile]] conditions, allowing the presence of microorganisms. The most common yeast to referment wine is the standard wine fermentation yeast ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'', but has also been attributed to ''[[Schizosaccharomyces pombe]]'' and ''[[Zygosaccharomyces bailii]]''.<ref name=duToitM/> The main issues associated with the fault include [[turbidity]] (from yeast [[biomass]] production), excess ethanol production (may violate [[wine label|labelling]] laws), slight [[carbonation]], and some coarse odours. Refermentation can be prevented by bottling wines dry (with residual sugar levels <1.0g/L), sterile filtering wine prior to bottling, or adding preservative chemicals such as [[dimethyl dicarbonate]]. The [[Portuguese wine]] style known as "[[vinho verde|vinhos verdes]]" used to rely on this secondary fermentation in bottle to impart a slight [[spritz (wine)|spritziness]] to the wine, but now usually uses artificial carbonation.
== Bunch rots == Organisms responsible for bunch rot of grape berries are filamentous fungi, the most common of these being ''[[Botrytis cinerea]]'' (gray mold) However, there are a range of other fungi responsible for the rotting of grapes such as ''[[Aspergillus]]'' spp., ''[[Penicillium]]'' spp., and fungi found in subtropical climates (e.g., ''[[Colletotrichum]]'' spp. (ripe rot) and ''[[Greeneria uvicola]]'' (bitter rot)). A further group more commonly associated with diseases of the vegetative tissues of the vine can also infect grape berries (e.g., [[Botryosphaeriaceae]], ''[[Phomopsis viticola]]''). Compounds found in bunch rot affected grapes and wine are typically described as having mushroom, earthy odors and include geosmin, [[2-methylisoborneol]], [[1-octen-3-ol]], [[2-octen-1-ol]], [[fenchol]] and [[fenchone]].<ref>Grapevine bunch rots: impacts on wine composition, quality, and potential procedures for the removal of wine faults. Steel CC, Blackman JW and Schmidtke LM, J Agric Food Chem., 5 June 2013, volume 61, issue 22, pages 5189-5206, {{doi|10.1021/jf400641r}}</ref>
